title: Facebook has rejected proposed new Australian regulations as 'unfounded' and blasted the government for trying to interfere
text:
(Photo by Chip Somodevilla, Getty Images) The ACCC has got under Zuckerberg’s skin.

Facebook has made public its submission to Treasury on the government’s ‘Digital Platforms Inquiry’ — which put both it and Google under the microscope — blasting some of its recommendations and seeming to agree with others.

It remains resolute in its opposition to the idea that it wields any significant power in its negotiations with media companies.

Facebook does not support the suggestion that it should have to forewarn the ACCC of any future acquisitions or restrict advertisers in their targeting of users. It also remains on the fence about fighting fake news, suggesting too much of a crackdown could amount to censorship.

It does however support data portability — where users could move their data from platform to platform — as well as government inquiries into advertising technology, and increased funding for Australian media companies among other proposals.

After a period of 18 months under intense government scrutiny, Facebook has hit back.

Responding to the Australian Consumer Competition Commission’s (ACCC) final ‘Digital Platforms Inquiry’ report, Facebook did not mince words.

“The Final Report’s analysis does not rest on a sound evidence base. It draws unfounded conclusions based on a selective and incomplete view of the spaces in which we compete, including subscribing to outmoded distinctions between different advertising services,” it said in its submission on the report.

“There is no basis for the Australian Government to interfere in the commercial arrangements between large companies … and Facebook.”

READ MORE: The Australian government has dropped its big report into big tech — here’s what it means for Google and Facebook

While the ACCC didn’t provide evidence of anti-competitive behaviour, it did warn that Facebook’s size and influence threaten market competition and consumer privacy. Here’s what Facebook thinks about the main new rules proposed by the ACCC.

Facebook agrees that a code be formed to combat fake news online but it shouldn’t enable censorship

Despite struggling to contain the content that is shared on its platform, Facebook remains on the fence about the need for any code to stop the spread of disinformation online.

“The Final Report does not contain an accurate or comprehensive evidence base suggesting that there is a public policy problem necessitating a regulator-enforced code as an effective solution at this stage,” it said.

While supporting the idea in principle, it said consultation is required to avoid “potential censorship implications”.

Facebook flatly refuses to notify the ACCC of any plans it has to acquire smaller companies

One of the key drivers with regards to the lack of competition is the fact large companies like Google and Facebook can simply buy out any threats to their dominance. Facebook for example already owns Instagram and WhatsApp. The ACCC, therefore, is interested in knowing of any future acquisitions ahead of time. Facebook does not agree.

“This recommendation is not supported by evidence of any existing gap in, or problem with, Australia’s merger laws or processes, that would necessitate such new measures.”

Facebook supports greater funding for Australian media

From tax incentives designed to boost philanthropic support of media companies to providing grants for local journalism and providing stable funding to public broadcasters, Facebook supported all recommendations designed to help the media industry.

It also tried to boast that it was doing its bit on that front, with its recent program of funding for small media projects.

READ MORE: Australian media companies are now making exclusive content for Facebook, just weeks after they slammed the platform

But it wholly disputes that it wields any power over media companies

One of Facebook’s main arguments is that there is no power imbalance between it and Australian media businesses.

“It is hard to imagine that such influential companies require the assistance of the Australian Government to negotiate commercial terms with Facebook, especially in light of the lack of evidence or findings of unfair trading on our part,” it said, arguing that the media has been undergoing a transformation since before the advent of Facebook in 2004.

While that may be true, the social media behemoth also doubled down, disputing that the loss of referrals from Facebook to news sites would amount to a substantial drop in revenue.

The proposition that Facebook isn’t a key driver of online traffic for media businesses is a stretch at best. So too is the following suggestion that media companies could mitigate traffic reductions by having “users accessing the website or app directly, or via a search engine”.

If Facebook could be avoided altogether by media companies, then the ACCC’s list of recommendations could have been far more succinct.

Facebook agrees with a code of conduct and privacy reform in principle but doesn’t support Australian proposals

In principle, Facebook says it believes in a code of conduct for platforms that spread news and the need to do more to protect user privacy. However, it takes issue with the path proposed by the ACCC, arguing that advertisers should be allowed to proactively target users.

It wants users to be empowered to move their information around

Data portability — the ability for users to move their own information from one platform to another — was a key ACCC recommendation to encourage competition. Facebook agrees, with one reservation.

“There are privacy considerations that need to be addressed to ensure that portability mechanisms are safe and easy to use,” it said.

Facebook wants the government to go after advertising tech companies

After 18 months of being scrutinised, Facebook thinks its time the government looked elsewhere and sees the ACCC recommendation that ad-tech companies be examined as just the ticket.

While it may hope that serves as a distraction, the ACCC’s recommendations have put the Australian government and Facebook on a collision course from which neither can divert.

It’s now up to the former to figure out exactly how to get Facebook to toe the line.
